description.narrative: Grantmaking to movements and communities of PLHIV/LGBTIQ/SW and PWUD in Uganda towards the protection, promotion and fulfillment of their sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) by contributing to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) 3 and 5 and result areas 4 and 1 of the Dutch MoFA SRHR strategy.
First and Final disbursement to partner-LA-UG1
First and final tranche to partner-LA-UG2

title.narrative: S1. Diverse KP communities are organised and meaningfully inclusive and have strengthened their capacity to claim their rights and freedoms.
Description of the link between Love Alliance indicators with MoFA basket indicators
S1.2 # of civil society organisations and community led organisations with increased capacity to advocate for the rights of key populations.

description.narrative: # of women-led CSOs with increased L&A capacities

comment.narrative: The national HIV strategy recognises men who have sex with men (MSM), people who inject drugs (PWID), and sex workers (SW) as key populations, and adolescent key populations are also distinctly included. Transgender people are not formally recognised as a key population (UNAIDS LPA, 2021).

At least 10 KP women-led civil society organisations and community led organisations in Uganda with increased capacity to advocate for the rights of key populations. This is a target for all the 5 years i.e. 2021 - 2025

In Q4 2021 UHAI's PGC awarded grants to KP organisations led by women to cater for their core costs and support their programmatic work towards advocacy for the rights of KP communities in Uganda. Implementation of these activities started in Q1 and Q2 2022, therefore results will be posted in the next reporting cycle.

title.narrative: S1.2 # of civil society organisations and community led organisations with increased capacity to advocate for the rights of key populations.

comment.narrative: The national HIV strategy recognises men who have sex with men (MSM), people who inject drugs (PWID), and sex workers (SW) as key populations, and adolescent key populations are also distinctly included. Transgender people are not formally recognised as a key population (UNAIDS LPA, 2021).

At least 10 KP-led civil society organisations and community led organisations with increased capacity to advocate for the rights of key populations. This is a target for all the 5 years i.e. 2021 - 2025

4 KP-led organisations were supported to increase their institutional capacity to advocate for KP rights.
1. Partner’s peer educators raised awareness on HIV prevention and SRHR services such as family planning and safe abortion on a daily basis.
2. Grantee partner has been able to develop funding proposals and are planning for the review of organisational policies and their Annual General Meeting (AGM). The Partners have conducted an outreach on free Voluntary HIV Counselling and Testing with The AIDS Support Organisation (TASO) and plan to conduct another with a legal litigation organisation.
3. 20 participants including staff members, board members, partners and members from grantee partner organisation participated in a strategic focus development workshop. Participants have a deeper understanding of the direction for grantee partner organisation and developed a road map to align the organization’s functional activities to achieve set goals and objectives.
4. To ensure full accountability to grantee partner beneficiaries, supporters, allies, partners and government on the operations of the organization as well as mark 17 years of their existence through an annual general meeting and Print the annual report. Results 1 annual general meeting was conducted and 100 copies of the annual report printed with 80 people attended. Produced a documentary highlighting the 17-year journey of Spectrum Uganda. Compliance with government requirements. Approved audit report 2019.

title.narrative: L1. Key population movements are capable, inclusive, influential and mutually supportive.
Description of the link between Love Alliance indicators with MoFA basket indicators
L1.1 Key populations effectively use accountability mechanisms towards SRHR.

description.narrative: Description of effective use of accountability mechanisms by citizens/communities and civil society organizations towards SRHR of all people.

comment.narrative:
Within Uganda's well-developed HIV response, there are accountability mechanisms which may be used for SRHR issues; there is no practice of accountability for key populations SRHR within SRHR-specific mechanisms.
There are several possible accountability mechanisms in place, such as the FAC Public Participation Mechanism, the national steering committee for key populations and national steering committee on prevention both at the Uganda AIDS Commission, and the Technical Working Group for Key Populations at the Ministry of Health. No systematic data are currently available on the frequency of use of these mechanisms specifically for SRHR accountability.
Increased capacity of key populations to utilise available mechanisms to advance the SRHR agenda in Uganda. Qualitatitve indicator for 5 years i.e. 2021 - 2025

1 Grantee partner in Uganda participated in various engagements on the EAC SRH 2021 Bill including a session on feminist analysis of the bill convened by Akina Mama wa Afrika (AMWA). Other partners engaged were The Eastern Africa National Networks of AIDS and Health Service Organizations (EANNASO), Outright International and CEHURD). AMWA, EANNASO, Outright International and CEHURD formed a national platform to move work on the analysis of the draft 2019 EAC SRH Bill. Results A safe space was created at the EAC SRH Bill engagements which enabled LGBTIQ community members to share their views about the proposed Bill.The draft 2019 EAC SRH Bill is legislation proposed at the regional level. However, there is advocacy work happening at national level aiming at influencing the provisions of this proposed Bill directly affecting KPs Partner was enabled to assess community needs and existing knowledge gaps in legal compliance. Partner’s advocacy responses and strategies were informed by the knowledge gained from community members and other stakeholders during the engagements. Grantee partner was further enabled to engage with Ugandan legislators on the views of the LGBTIQ community about the proposed EAC SRH Bill.
